title: Lesson A1-4 Assessment: Additional Difficult Sounds

questions.question: How is the trilled რ [r] produced?

options.text: By vibrating the tongue tip against the alveolar ridge
By making a sound at the back of the throat
By closing the glottis and releasing

questions.explanation: The trilled რ [r] is produced by vibrating the tongue tip against the alveolar ridge (that bumpy part just behind your upper teeth). The tongue should vibrate rapidly, creating a 'rolling' or 'trilling' sound.

questions.question: What is the difference between ღ [ɣ] and ხ [x]?

options.text: ღ is voiced (with vibration), ხ is voiceless (no vibration)
ხ is voiced, ღ is voiceless
One is ejective, one is not

questions.explanation: ღ [ɣ] is a voiced guttural fricative - you feel vibration in your throat. ხ [x] is a voiceless guttural fricative - no vibration, just throat friction. Both are made at the back of the throat.

questions.question: Match the sounds to their descriptions:

rightItems.text: Voiced guttural fricative - throat sound with vibration
Voiceless guttural fricative - throat sound without vibration

questions.explanation: რ [r] is the trilled r (tongue vibration), ღ [ɣ] is voiced guttural (throat with voice), ხ [x] is voiceless guttural (throat without voice).

questions.question: Which word contains a complex consonant cluster?
questions.explanation: გრძელი [grdzeli] contains the cluster 'grdz' - four consonants in a row! Georgian is famous for complex consonant clusters like this.

questions.question: Complete: __ამე (night - uses voiced guttural):
questions.explanation: ღამე [ɣame] uses voiced guttural ღ [ɣ]. Remember: voiced means you feel vibration in your throat when pronouncing it!

questions.question: Complete: __არი (bull - uses voiceless guttural):
questions.explanation: ხარი [xari] uses voiceless guttural ხ [x]. No vibration - just throat friction. Similar to German 'ch' in 'Bach'.

questions.question: What's the best strategy for practicing consonant clusters?

options.text: Start slow, pronounce each consonant separately, then speed up
Always say them as fast as possible
Only practice one consonant at a time

questions.explanation: The best strategy is to start slow and pronounce each consonant separately (gr-dz-eli), then gradually speed up until you can say it smoothly (grdzeli). This builds muscle memory and helps you master complex clusters!
